title: ## Reading List: Long Sequences & Document-Level Representation Learning

This list covers a range of topics, from foundational work to recent advancements in long sequence and document-level representation learning. It includes both theoretical and practical aspects, with a focus on deep learning approaches
**"Recurrent Neural Networks" by Elman (1990):** A seminal work introducing the concept of recurrent neural networks (RNNs) for processing sequential data
**"Long Short-Term Memory" by Hochreiter & Schmidhuber (1997):** Introduces the LSTM architecture, addressing the vanishing gradient problem in RNNs and enabling learning long-term dependencies
**"A Neural Probabilistic Language Model" by Bengio et al
Demonstrates the effectiveness of neural networks for language modeling, paving the way for modern NLP applications
**"Distributed Representations of Words and Phrases and their Compositionality" by Mikolov et al
Introduces word2vec, a popular method for learning distributed word representations
**"Sequence to Sequence Learning with Neural Networks" by Sutskever et al
Introduces the encoder-decoder framework for sequence-to-sequence learning, enabling tasks like machine translation
**Long Sequence Modeling:**
**"Attention Is All You Need" by Vaswani et al
Introduces the Transformer architecture, which uses attention mechanisms to process long sequences without relying on recurrent connections
Extends the Transformer architecture to handle arbitrarily long sequences by introducing a novel attention mechanism
**"Reformer: The Efficient Transformer" by Kitaev et al
Proposes a more efficient Transformer architecture by using locality-sensitive hashing and reversible layers
**"Longformer: The Long-Document Transformer" by Beltagy et al
Introduces a Transformer variant with a novel attention mechanism that allows it to process long documents efficiently
**"BigBird: Transformers for Longer Sequences" by Zaheer et al
Presents a Transformer architecture that uses a sparse attention mechanism to handle long sequences
**Document-Level Representation Learning:**
**"Sentence Embeddings: A Survey" by Arora et al
Provides a comprehensive overview of different approaches for learning sentence embeddings
**"Universal Sentence Encoder" by Cer et al
Introduces a pre-trained model for learning sentence embeddings that can be used for various downstream tasks
Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding" by Devlin et al
Introduces BERT, a powerful pre-trained language model that achieves state-of-the-art results on various NLP tasks
**"XLNet: Generalized Autoregressive Pretraining for Language Understanding" by Yang et al
Presents XLNet, a pre-trained language model that uses a generalized autoregressive approach to learn better representations
**"RoBERTa: A Robustly Optimized BERT Pretraining Approach" by Liu et al
Introduces RoBERTa, a variant of BERT that achieves improved performance through better training techniques
**"Document-Level Representation Learning with Transformers" by Liu et al
Explores the use of Transformers for learning document-level representations, achieving state-of-the-art results on various tasks
**"Sentence-BERT: Sentence Embeddings using Siamese BERT-Networks" by Reimers & Gurevych (2019):** Introduces Sentence-BERT, a method for learning sentence embeddings using Siamese BERT networks
**"A Survey of Document Embeddings" by Arora et al
Provides a comprehensive overview of different approaches for learning document embeddings
**"Neural Machine Translation by Jointly Learning to Align and Translate" by Bahdanau et al
Demonstrates the use of attention mechanisms for machine translation
**"Deep Learning for Text Summarization: A Comprehensive Survey" by Nallapati et al
Provides a comprehensive overview of deep learning approaches for text summarization

This list is not exhaustive, but it provides a good starting point for exploring the field of long sequences and document-level representation learning. You can find more articles and resources by searching online databases like Google Scholar and arXiv
